The electric guitar discussion makes me wonder, when does a clue go from being misleading to out-and-out wrong?  We always say that it's not necessarily the most common example that is used in a clue, as long as the answer is a lesser-used but accepted example of the clue.  We had that the other day with adaptor/adapter, and there's at least one every day.  

But what if only one supporting example can be found, and it's quite rare?  Like the specific guitar Jim mentioned.  Particularly because that Gibson is an acoustic/electric guitar (something I didn't even know existed) and not a pure electric.

Maybe the rule should be that such "misdirection" should be avoided if there's no wordplay, and if the level of difficulty is made greater because people with greater familiarity to the subject consider the clue wrong because it's suggesting that something that's far outside the norm is a regular characteristic of the item involved.  Certainly, [Stereo knob] would have worked just as well, without giving anything away.

So [Mythical luster] is fine because it plays on "luster" being one who lusts (a new one to go with shower, flower, etc.) instead of being a sheen.  But the guitar clue isn't really great because it's just obfuscating rather than misdirecting.

Was thrilled to learn that our trick-or-treating will actually be on Oct. 31 this year, and last a whole 2 hours. When I was a kid, it started as soon as we got home from school. For my kidlets, it was as soon as they scarfed down the pizza for dinner (I had all their friends start at my house because most of their moms had jobs that were not as flexible as mine). I got them painted and costumed, and out we went. My son was done after one block. "That's enough," he would say. My daughter and her friends would be out for a good two to three hours, in our heavily populated suburb. 

Now I live in an area where, if we get 20 kids, it's a lot, and they came together in vans from who knows where. I don't care, we're prepared. 

George, our household ghost, loves Halloween, and is already preparing. Yesterday he messed with my Keurig machine, turning it off mid-pour. He also turns water spigots on and off, and plays with our stereo system. I'll be glad when the holiday is over and he settles down again.

Something I learned today is that when Albin Grau wanted to make a film based on Bram Stoker's 'Dracula,' he was forced by copyright restrictions to make various changes to the narrative. This introduced certain vampiric tropes that now seem ubiquitous, but weren't present in the original text. For instance, in Stoker's novel, vampires were only slightly harmed by sunlight, whereas in Grau's 'Nosferatu', they get burned to a crisp. In the end however, Grau still wasn't able to evade a lawsuit! (Source: Copyright Alliance)

Most trick-or-treating here involves little to no tricking.  It's mostly children going around in costumes knocking on their neighbors' doors for candy.  It was that way when I was a kid in the 60s, and it's still that way today.  

Pranks are usually carried out by bored teenagers, but they are rare, and frowned upon.  

What bothers me about the commercialization of everything is that now the year ends with the months of September, Halloween, Christmas and Christmas.  Although Thanksgiving is my favorite holiday, November is already consumed with Christmas everywhere.  Too much, too soon, too long.  And to a certain extent, the same is true of Halloween.

Regarding the U.S. tradition of trick-or-treating, at least where I live, there are customs/rules which make the event more enjoyable for all. For example,  the expectation here is that kids should only visit homes with the porch lights turned on (or other obvious decor), which is seen as an invitation to knock/ring. Also, there are specific hours designated within many areas (18:00-20:00, e.g.) which limits the disruption. 

There is very little ‚Äútricking‚Äù, except perhaps the candy companies fooling us all into buying irrational amounts of sweet treats. üòÖ Certainly some unruly teens smash a few pumpkins, or perhaps TP a frenemy‚Äôs house, which most would say is bad form. @Steve L
As any fule kno (English saying) Halloween was recorded in 16th century Scotland. 
As a child in Edinburgh, (1950s) we went out 'guising' ie dressed up, (always home-made) and thus disguised to fool evil spirits, we went round neighbours' houses. We didn't say 'trick or treat' but children were expected to perform - sing a song, say poem or do a dance in order to get a treat, usually one sweet or a biscuit.

We would carve out turnip/swede lanterns, very hard work. 

There were Halloween parties when you 'dooked' for apples (others call it apple bobbing) when you tried to grab an apple with your teeth from a tub of water, hands behind your back. Another version was to drop a fork from your mouth into the water to try and spear an apple. Cub Scouts and Brownies always had these parties.

There were also treacle scones - scones or slices of bread (pieces) were smeared with black treacle (molasses?) and threaded though a string and hung up. We had to try and take a bite of the treacle piece, hands behind back, while the mean adults jiggled the string about.

So it wasn‚Äôt hard for that to develop into the equivalent of Halloween, where kids would dress up in any costume. I don‚Äôt think they really ‚Äútrick or treat‚Äù and go door to door but there is generally a lot of parties and treats to be had. It‚Äôs kind of like how Hannukah became the equivalent of Christmas in the US, even though they are fundamentally different and Hannukah would otherwise have been a minor Jewish holiday.

As a kid I was encouraged by both my parents to explore spirituality and religion on my own. My mother was an atheist, and my father an agnostic (he has since progressed to atheism, too). My best friend ≈Åukasz came from a religious, Calvinist family though, and the way he and his parents talked about god and what he meant in their lives sounded quite nice. I was fascinated, and very close to becoming a believer myself. My parents were ok with it.

Everything changed in 1989, when the old regime fell, and the new one introduced religion as an (optional) subject at school beginning in 1990, when I started 4th grade. Given my beliefs at the time I went to those classes enthusiastically and with an open mind. Quickly I became disenchanted. It was Catholic indoctrination, effectively. Nothing the teacher - a nun - said was even remotely close to the joyous image of faith I had been learning from ≈Åukasz. In 5th grade we got a new religion teacher - a middle aged priest. He was a bully who had no idea how to deal with preteens. He showed me the worst facets of Polish Catholicism, conservative, intolerant, allergic to joy, detached from rationality, and hypocritical. Within a year I was an atheist. Isn't it funny how religion classes, of all things, extinguished the religious spark in me?

At no time in this religious evolution of mine was I pressured by my parents.
